title: Tuesday, 10th May, 2016

11:13 am
BE

The £458m of Q1 contracts is a bit rubbish for Capita on any normal measure -- the YOY figure is £1.2bn -- but as you say, Brexit.

BE

Here's Barclays to sum things up.

BE

Capita confirms it is on track to achieve its guidance of “at least” 4% organic growth and expects to meet current consensus for FY16e. Reuters (and we) have EBITA of £680m and EPS of 74.4p, the latter +c5% yoy. 2% organic growth is booked YTD, consisting of mostly smaller ticket wins. To meet guidance, we estimate it needs 1% from the pipeline and c1% from further divisional growth. The software, insurance & benefits, pensions divisions are showing either good to improved growth on last year, which provides some comfort that they will get close to this.

· The pipeline is described as ‘active’ particularly in telecoms, financial services (private) and defence/local Gov (public) but Capita flags contract decisions are taking longer than expected to come through – i.e. any big ticket wins should be weighted to the 2H. To date Capita has secured contracts with value of £458m (up from £251m as at 25 Feb) – a proportion of which is rebids/ extensions. This compares to £1.2bn as at May 2015 and £1.1bn as at May 2014.

· Capita expects leverage of 2.0-2.5x for FY16 (FY15 2.5x) including a ‘regular flow of small to medium sized acquisitions’. We estimate this implies spend of c£250m in the year. The shares trade on c14x FY16e PE with a c6% FCF yield, trading at relative lows.

· Contracts won/extended include a £139m contract for five district councils, preferred bidder status to become a technical services partner to Blackburn with Darwen Council and extensions with Volkswagen and a major financial services client.

· Four acquisitions have been announced for total spend of £23m: these include a digital agency for BPO work and a payments business. The group has disposed of Capital Medical and Fish Administration, both of which were held-for-sale as at FY15 results. The disposals should deliver proceeds of c£40m with monies from Capital Medical (roughly half of the sum) being received in the 2H.

11:15 am
BE

And Stifel.

BE

YTD contract wins totalling £458m (as of February 2016 £251m) which the
company sees as a solid start to the year. To put these numbers in context,
YTD contract wins in May 2014 were £1.1bn and in May 2015 £1.2bn, helped
by some large contracts. This highlights the dearth of notable contract
announcements, a trend ongoing since last summer.
On the bid pipeline, the key driver of organic growth which stood at £4.7bn
at the prelims, today’s statement notes key areas of activity being telecoms,
financials services, defence, local government, science & health. No changes
of note there. However, “contract decisions are taking a little longer than
expected to come through”. Capita highlights that it expects a flow of bid
outcomes over the rest of the year.
Acquisition activity on the low side: Four companies have been acquired
for a total consideration of £23m. This compares to £215m at this stage last
year which included Avocis (£157m). Leverage is anticipated to be within a
2.0-2.5x range by year-end depending on the level of acquisitions in the
remainder of the year.
We are SELLers of the stock. We think Capita has lost some of its sparkle,
we have concerns over medium-term organic growth prospects and value
creation from M&A. Today’s statement does little to reassure us.

BE

So that's the most exciting corporate news of the day done.

11:22 am
BE

Barclays incoming.

BE

easyJet has reported H1 loss before tax of £24m, inline with company-collected consensus. Focus for the market is firmly on the outlook statement: the company is expecting a very weak June quarter, driven by Brussels terror attacks and Easter timing. However, H2 pricing guidance implies easyJet is much more confident on the peak summer quarter, citing beach routes in particular. The raised payout ratio (50% of net profit) is also a positive, putting the company on a 5% FY16 dividend yield. The target to keep ex-fuel unit costs flat in the medium term was well anticipated, although it may be back end loaded with a chance of unit costs rising in FY2017, returning to FY15 levels by FY19.

Mathematically, easyJet’s new guidance implies a PBT range of £680m-£720m, compared to Bloomberg consensus at £720m: however, we believe the buy side was already anticipating a ~£700m PBT guide, and we are not surprised to see a relatively flat reaction in the share price this morning. We expect questions at the analysts’ meeting on the company’s confidence in Q4 at this relatively early stage, especially given the tough comparable last year and our assumption that less than 40% of seats have been sold so far. If easyJet is right about the strength of the summer, it is also very good readthrough to Ryanair.

· H1 summary. H1 RPS (pricing) was down 4.2%, broadly inline with our expectations and particularly impacted by Paris attacks and the suspension of flying to Sharm el-Sheikh. Ex-fuel CPS was +0.5% (vs guidance +1%), with the company highlighting airport volume incentives, ground handling, maintenance and crew cost savings.

· Trading outlook. RPS in the June quarter is guided to be ~ -7% (despite Q3 2015 being -2.8%) – the main issues flagged are Brussels attacks suppressing bookings in April and May, movement of Easter, and a small impact from the suspension of Egypt routes. However, Q4 trading is looking strong, in particular on beach routes (which make up one third of the network). The guidance of RPS to be down low to mid single digits across H2 as a whole implies flattish to slightly down pricing in Q4.

· Cost outlook. Cost guidance for the year has again been improved: now expected to be down 1% in FY16, which would imply -2% in H2. The company is highlighting Lean savings, especially airport contracts and Engineering and Maintenance. We would also highlight there were significant one-off costs in the prior year comparable (Rome Fiumicino fire, Eurocontrol charge).

· Fuel/FX. There are small changes to fuel and FX guidance (FY16 unit fuel now £170m-£180m tailwind vs prior £165m-£180m, FY16 FX now £55m vs £50m headwind).

BE

And Davy.

11:23 am
BE

This is a relatively robust performance from easyJet. Loss
before tax at -£24m (in H1) was broadly in line with market
estimates of -£26m. H1 unit revenue was down 4.2% per seat
(at constant currency), including -4.7% in Q2. Taking into
account the timing of Easter and the effects of terrorism in
Brussels, easyJet expects third-quarter revenue per seat to
decline by around seven percentage points. It expects revenue
per seat at constant currency for the second half of the financial
year to decrease by low- to mid-single-digit percentage points
(this would imply flattish unit revenues in peak summer).
Bookings are currently in line with the prior year. Other
headlines are the CFO’s cost and capital structure review, which
includes a target of flat cost per seat excluding fuel for the
2015-2019 period and an increase in the dividend pay-out to
50%. Overall, we are likely to trim our £739.2m estimates, but
only modestly, to closer to c.£720m. Overall, a robust
performance.

PM

(georgew -- certainly. Just fill out the little form and i will click you through)

11:24 am
BE

■ 1H PBT loss of £24m and outlook as expected, cost control designed to
distribute more cash: EZJ has reported a PBT loss of £24m for 1H, in line
with CS at £25m and consensus of £26m, and confirmed 2016 profit
expectations remain in line with market expectations (Bloomberg consensus
PBT £726m, Reuters £717m). Management has also confirmed it expects to
hold ex-fuel unit costs flat to 2019 (assuming "normal" levels of disruption)
while following a review of the capital structure, EZJ plans to propose an
annual dividend based on a new payout ratio of 50% (up from 40%) from
FY16 onward as it targets maintenance of its current investment grade credit
rating (Baa1 per Moody's). We trim PBT by 1% in 2016E to £722m albeit by
5% in FY17E-FY18E given an uptick in market wide fuel tailwind pass
through rates – our TP falls to 1,985p (vs 2,137p) suggesting 35% upside
potential before a 5% dividend yield.
■ 3Q pricing guidance starkly weak due to April, but underlying trends
more benign: Following a 4.2% decline in 1H, easyJet expects revenue per
seat to decline by 7% yoy at constant currency in 3Q, driven by April
weakness post-Brussels and Easter timing. We expect April to have seen up
to a double digit rate of decline, before May/June see moderation to a low-to-
mid single digit run rate which EZJ expects to continue into 4Q. Ex-fuel unit
costs should decrease by 1% at CC for FY driven by EZJ Lean savings,
following growth of 0.5% in 1H (prior guidance 0-1% growth). The unit fuel bill
should fall by £170m-£180m in FY16 while FX should hit 2H by £20m
following a £35m impact in 1H.
■ Outperform with a TP of 1,985p suggesting 35% upside potential before
5% dividend yield: EZJ offers a sustainable lease-adjusted ROIC near to 3x
its cost of capital, with a real asset base to grow mid-single digits over the
medium-to-long term. We estimate a 5.5% 2016E FCF yield (5% dividend
yield).

BE

The Group produces some of its cocoa on its plantation in Saint Lucia, sources beans from other Saint Lucian growers and operates a hotel, spa and restaurant on the plantation. As previously announced, Massimo Tosato, currently Executive Vice Chairman and Global Head of Distribution, will be retiring from the Board on 31 December 2016 to pursue his entrepreneurial ambitions. In anticipation of that, Mr Tosato will start to hand over his responsibilities as Global Head of Distribution to a combination of John Troiano, who will become Global Head of Distribution and Richard Mountford, who will become Global Head of Product. Both John Troiano and Richard Mountford will report to Peter Harrison, Group Chief Executive.

Mr Tosato will continue to support Peter Harrison and the business during the transition process and will retain a number of roles and board positions within the firm.

Philip Mallinckrodt will take on responsibility as Group Head of Private Assets in addition to his overall responsibilities for Wealth Management. Andrew Ross will become Global Head of Wealth Management and will continue to report to Philip Mallinckrodt.

11:47 am
BE

Advertising forecasts reduced again: The latest media buyer and sales
house feedback is that UK TV ad trends are deteriorating. We now look for zero
ad growth for ITV Family in May (was 1%) and +5% for June (was 10%). This
means that we look for ITV Family advertising (ex-Ulster) to be down 1.3% in
Q2, and down 0.6% in H1, despite the benefit from Euro 2016. Our H2 forecast
is for 0.5% growth for ITV Family ex Ulster, meaning we now see a marginal
decline in advertising for 2016 ( was +1%). Given we entered 2016 at +3.5%,
our ad revenue forecast has fallen by over £50m since the start of the year. We
look for 1.3% growth in 2017 (was 1.5%) and 2.5% for 2017-18.
Brexit or UK slowdown or both? The initial reaction from media buyers to
the April-June slowdown was that it was potentially related to advertiser
caution ahead of the Brexit vote, particularly given the six-eight week booking
cycles in TV. With three of the top four categories at ITV (retail, food, finance)
looking weak, the commentary from industry participants is increasingly that
this is simply a soft advertising environment. There appears little expectation
from ITV or media buyers that ‘lost’ H1 advertising will be recovered in H2.

BE

Group forecasts reduced: The reduction to -0.2% ad growth in 2016 and
1.3% in 2017 means our eps forecasts fall by 2% in 2016 and by 3-4% in
2017-19. Since the start of the year our 2016-18 eps forecasts have reduced
by 7-9%. Eps growth in 2016 is forecast at 3% and at 6% pa 2016-19e.
Reduced to EW : Our price target falls to 260p, as we take out the 10p special
dividend and reduce by an underlying 5%. At 260p, ITV would trade at a 2016
p/e of 15.3x (2017 14.2x) and a TCR of 6.6%. The broadcaster group 2017 p/e
range is 23.6x (Mediaset) to 13.8x (RTL) with an average of 16.1x. The risk at
ITV, where the story relies heavily on operational gearing against a flat
programming cost base, is continued advertising forecast downgrades.
What could go right for ITV? (i) ITV is likely to confirm the weaker ad trends
with its Q1 on Thursday but overall revenues are forecast up 7% (ii) We think
the audience performance at ITV is relatively strong ytd (iii) As a UK cyclical ITV
should respond positively to a Remain decision in the Brexit vote on June 23rd
(iv) At 218p ITV trades at a modest 2016 p/e of 12.8x and has a potential total
cash return of 7.9% in 2016.

BE

Citi note on estate agents.

11:54 am
BE

Warming a little on Foxtons.

BE

Sector Review
We undertake a sector review following the recent Q1 trading updates for the UK listed Estate Agent peers. Given uncertainties ahead of the Brexit vote on June 23rd, we generally retain a cautious stance on the space. We look at underlying market trends impacting the UK Sales and Lettings markets currently. We note strength in the market in Q1 ahead of the stamp duty changes impacting the Buy-to-Let and second home market, however take a cautious overall view on the rest of the year.
Flat 2016 Sales Expected
Despite the strong start to the year (Q1 sales +37%), we model flat volumes for FY16. This suggests that Q2-Q4 could see a -8.2% volume performance YoY and still deliver Citi expectations of flat FY16 overall sales transactions. On the stock specifics, following the Q1 update, we suggest Countrywide could deliver -7.5% decline in volumes and still meet expectations whilst LSL and Foxtons volumes could decline by -7.1 and -4.9% respectively.
Brexit The Key Risk
Citi Economists continue to put the probability that the UK votes to leave the EU at 30-40%, i.e. not our base case, but my no means trivial. Given the London-centric nature of the financial and business services sector, Citi Economists suggest that it would not be a surprise if Brexit triggered a re-run of the London house price drop seen in 2007-09 (roughly -18%). Within the note we model Brexit scenarios for all three operators, suggesting c34-36% downside risk to FY17e earnings estimates for all three in such scenario, with Foxtons, given its London focus, seeing marginally more impact than peers.

BE

umbers Updated
Largely on the back of updated market assumptions, we revise estimates. We also derive new price targets for LSL (TP 360p), Countrywide (TP 370p) and Foxtons (TP 140p) as we now utilise the long-term average EV/EBITDA of longest listed player, LSL. On recommendations, we retain our Buy on LSL and Neutral rating on Countrywide. We upgrade Foxtons to Neutral (from Sell). Whilst we continue to have concerns regarding London end-market dynamics, and despite the trim to our target price, we suggest the stock is now trading at close to fair value given current end market dynamics, and highlight the 8.3% dividend providing yield support.
